Peoples Party of Arunachal, a regional political party in the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh. It was founded in September 1979 by Bakin Pertin and Tomo Riba as president of the party. Currently, Kamen Ringu is the Chairman of the party. They were in power in Arunachal until all of their MLAs defected back to Indian National Congress.
On 16 September 2016, 43 MLAs from the ruling party, under the CM Pema Khandu, left Indian National Congress to join People's Party of Arunachal party, in alliance with Bharatiya Janata Party.


Following the election Pertin organised a meeting in Pasighat in April 1977, to found the People's Party of Arunachal.[2][3] Pertin became the president of the new party.[4] Whilst being the leader of PPA, Pertin was continued to be linked to the Janata Party then in government in Delhi.[5] Pertin had the status of being an 'associated' member of the Janata Party. He later broke his links with the Janata Party.[6][7]
In 1979, Tomo Riba became the President of the party and was the Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh in a short lived government spaninng from September 1979 to November 1979 with total of 47 days. After this party had little success in Arunachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly.
In 1989, Tomo Riba left the party and joined Janata Dal and Gegong Apang became leader of party.
Currently it is a part of North-East Regional Political Front consisting of political parties of the northeast which has supported the National Democratic Alliance (India).
In December 2015, 30 dissident Indian National Congress MLAs including chief minister, Kalikho Pul joined Peoples Party of Arunachal and formed the government along with Bharatiya Janata Party.[8]
In May 2016, after the Bharatiya Janata Party led National Democratic Alliance formed its first government in Assam, a new alliance called the North-East Democratic Alliance (NEDA) was formed with Himanta Biswa Sarma as its convener. The Chief Ministers of the north eastern states of Sikkim, Assam and Nagaland too belong to this alliance. Thus, the People's Party of Arunachal joined the BJP led NEDA.[9]
All of the 30 MLAs returned to Indian National Congress on 16 July 2016 and Pema Khandu was sworn in as the Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh.
On 16 September 2016, 43 MLAs from the ruling party, under the CM Pema Khandu, left Indian National Congress to join People's Party of Arunachal party, in alliance with Bharatiya Janata Party. Though Pema Khandu is still the Chief minister, it is soon expected that either a coalition government will be formed with BJP as the speaker of assembly has also changed sides with the CM, or that the Indian Government will dissolve the state assembly for a fresh general elections.[10]
In October 2016, Pema Khandu, Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh formally joined hands with Bharatiya Janata Party, making Arunachal Pradesh 14th state to have BJP in Power,[11] and with this new coalition, Tamiyo Taga sworn-in as Cabinet minister of Arunachal Pradesh.[12]
On December 21, 2016, Pema Khandu was suspended from the party by the party president Kahfa Bengia and Takam Pario was named as the next likely Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh replacing Khandu after People's Party of Arunachal suspended Khandu along with 6 other MLAs.[13][14][15]
On December, 2016, Pema Khandu proved majority on the floor with 33 of the People's Party of Arunachal’s 43 legislators joining the Bharatiya Janata Party as the BJP party increased its strength to 45 and it has the support of two independents. He became second Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh of Bharatiya Janata Party in Arunachal Pradesh after 44 days lead Gegong Apang government in 2003.[16][17]

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal)

History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.

AIMS AND OBJECTIVE OF THE PARTY :


The following shall be the aims and objectives of the Party: (i) stands for decentralisation of economic and political power;
(ii) bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and to the principles of equality, secularism and democracy and would uphold the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
(iii) assert the right to own, use, develop and control the land and resources that the people possess by reason of traditional ownership or other traditional occupation or use, as well as those which the people have otherwise inherited
(iv) assert the right to self-determination in regards to pursue of economic, social and cultural development. Right to maintain and strengthen own distinct political, legal, economic, social and cultural institutions
(v) assert the right to live in freedom, peace and security as distinct peoples
(vi) designate the indigenous names for places, rivers, mountain, etc
(vii) revive the past glory of self reliance; self confident, self esteemed, moral values & ethos and justly that prevailed in traditional society;
(viii) promoting economic growth and prosperity through competition, self reliance, individual initiative and enterprise with emphasis on equity and social justice
(ix) assert right to establish and control the educational systems and institutions, providing education in own languages, in a manner appropriate to cultural methods of teaching and learning. And all children shall have right to all levels and forms of modern education of the State without discrimination
(x) provide such the right to the people, without discrimination in the areas of education, employment, vocational training, housing, sanitation, health and social security
(xi) combat against all forms of prejudice, discrimination and corruption
(xii) prepare a ground for peaceful co-existence of the different indigenous communities and promote tolerance, understanding and good relations among people
(xiii) ensure that women and children enjoy the full protection and guarantees against all forms of violence and discrimination
(xiv) ensure the right of the women to participate in decision making

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal)

History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.

AIMS AND OBJECTIVE OF THE PARTY :


The following shall be the aims and objectives of the Party: (i) stands for decentralisation of economic and political power;
(ii) bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and to the principles of equality, secularism and democracy and would uphold the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
(iii) assert the right to own, use, develop and control the land and resources that the people possess by reason of traditional ownership or other traditional occupation or use, as well as those which the people have otherwise inherited
(iv) assert the right to self-determination in regards to pursue of economic, social and cultural development. Right to maintain and strengthen own distinct political, legal, economic, social and cultural institutions
(v) assert the right to live in freedom, peace and security as distinct peoples
(vi) designate the indigenous names for places, rivers, mountain, etc
(vii) revive the past glory of self reliance; self confident, self esteemed, moral values & ethos and justly that prevailed in traditional society;
(viii) promoting economic growth and prosperity through competition, self reliance, individual initiative and enterprise with emphasis on equity and social justice
(ix) assert right to establish and control the educational systems and institutions, providing education in own languages, in a manner appropriate to cultural methods of teaching and learning. And all children shall have right to all levels and forms of modern education of the State without discrimination
(x) provide such the right to the people, without discrimination in the areas of education, employment, vocational training, housing, sanitation, health and social security
(xi) combat against all forms of prejudice, discrimination and corruption
(xii) prepare a ground for peaceful co-existence of the different indigenous communities and promote tolerance, understanding and good relations among people

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal)

History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.

AIMS AND OBJECTIVE OF THE PARTY :


The following shall be the aims and objectives of the Party: (i) stands for decentralisation of economic and political power;
(ii) bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and to the principles of equality, secularism and democracy and would uphold the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
(iii) assert the right to own, use, develop and control the land and resources that the people possess by reason of traditional ownership or other traditional occupation or use, as well as those which the people have otherwise inherited
(iv) assert the right to self-determination in regards to pursue of economic, social and cultural development. Right to maintain and strengthen own distinct political, legal, economic, social and cultural institutions

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal)
History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.

The following shall be the aims and objectives of the Party: (i) stands for decentralisation of economic and political power;
(ii) bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and to the principles of equality, secularism and democracy and would uphold the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
(iii) assert the right to own, use, develop and control the land and resources that the people possess by reason of traditional ownership or other traditional occupation or use, as well as those which the people have otherwise inherited
(iv) assert the right to self-determination in regards to pursue of economic, social and cultural development. Right to maintain and strengthen own distinct political, legal, economic, social and cultural institutions
(v) assert the right to live in freedom, peace and security as distinct peoples
(vi) designate the indigenous names for places, rivers, mountain, etc
(vii) revive the past glory of self reliance; self confident, self esteemed, moral values & ethos and justly that prevailed in traditional society;
(viii) promoting economic growth and prosperity through competition, self reliance, individual initiative and enterprise with emphasis on equity and social justice
(ix) assert right to establish and control the educational systems and institutions, providing education in own languages, in a manner appropriate to cultural methods of teaching and learning. And all children shall have right to all levels and forms of modern education of the State without discrimination
(x) provide such the right to the people, without discrimination in the areas of education, employment, vocational training, housing, sanitation, health and social security
(xi) combat against all forms of prejudice, discrimination and corruption
(xii) prepare a ground for peaceful co-existence of the different indigenous communities and promote tolerance, understanding and good relations among people
(xiii) ensure that women and children enjoy the full protection and guarantees against all forms of violence and discrimination
(xiv) ensure the right of the women to participate in decision making

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal
History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.

AIMS AND OBJECTIVE OF THE PARTY :
The following shall be the aims and objectives of the Party: (i) stands for decentralisation of economic and political power;
(ii) bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and to the principles of equality, secularism and democracy and would uphold the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
(iii) assert the right to own, use, develop and control the land and resources that the people possess by reason of traditional ownership or other traditional occupation or use, as well as those which the people have otherwise inherited
(iv) assert the right to self-determination in regards to pursue of economic, social and cultural development. Right to maintain and strengthen own distinct political, legal, economic, social and cultural institutions
(v) assert the right to live in freedom, peace and security as distinct peoples
(vi) designate the indigenous names for places, rivers, mountain, etc
(vii) revive the past glory of self reliance; self confident, self esteemed, moral values & ethos and justly that prevailed in traditional society;
(viii) promoting economic growth and prosperity through competition, self reliance, individual initiative and enterprise with emphasis on equity and social justice
(ix) assert right to establish and control the educational systems and institutions, providing education in own languages, in a manner appropriate to cultural methods of teaching and learning. And all children shall have right to all levels and forms of modern education of the State without discrimination
(x) provide such the right to the people, without discrimination in the areas of education, employment, vocational training, housing, sanitation, health and social security
(xi) combat against all forms of prejudice, discrimination and corruption
(xii) prepare a ground for peaceful co-existence of the different indigenous communities and promote tolerance, understanding and good relations among people
(xiii) ensure that women and children enjoy the full protection and guarantees against all forms of violence and discrimination
(xiv) ensure the right of the women to participate in decision making

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal
History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.

AIMS AND OBJECTIVE OF THE PARTY :
The following shall be the aims and objectives of the Party: (i) stands for decentralisation of economic and political power;
(ii) bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and to the principles of equality, secularism and democracy and would uphold the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
(iii) assert the right to own, use, develop and control the land and resources that the people possess by reason of traditional ownership or other traditional occupation or use, as well as those which the people have otherwise inherited
(iv) assert the right to self-determination in regards to pursue of economic, social and cultural development. Right to maintain and strengthen own distinct political, legal, economic, social and cultural institutions
(v) assert the right to live in freedom, peace and security as distinct peoples
(vi) designate the indigenous names for places, rivers, mountain, etc
(vii) revive the past glory of self reliance; self confident, self esteemed, moral values & ethos and justly that prevailed in traditional society;
(viii) promoting economic growth and prosperity through competition, self reliance, individual initiative and enterprise with emphasis on equity and social justice
(ix) assert right to establish and control the educational systems and institutions, providing education in own languages, in a manner appropriate to cultural methods of teaching and learning. And all children shall have right to all levels and forms of modern education of the State without discrimination
(x) provide such the right to the people, without discrimination in the areas of education, employment, vocational training, housing, sanitation, health and social security
(xi) combat against all forms of prejudice, discrimination and corruption
(xii) prepare a ground for peaceful co-existence of the different indigenous communities and promote tolerance, understanding and good relations among people
(xiii) ensure that women and children enjoy the full protection and guarantees against all forms of violence and discrimination

HISTORY OF PPA (People's Party of Arunachal
History of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) has a very clear and candid conception of regional development through regional planning in the framework of Indian constitution. The idea of regional political parties emerged as an alternative to the attempt of national political parties and frees its people from Bondage of High Commandism. This idea was carried on by All Leaders’ Conference on 10th April 1977 at Pasighat. Late Tomo Riba, Bakin Pertin, Tamar Karlo and others played leading role in shaping regional ideology in late 1970s. The constitution of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) was drafted by Mr. W. Lowangcha, as the Chairman with following member: Shri Jopak Tayeng Shri Somlang Handique Shri Thinghap Taju Shri Manfe Hosai Shri T. Dabi Shri H. Jamo Shri N. Longphi PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) is the first indigenous/ common people’s party in Arunachal Pradesh. This party emerged as true representative of the indigenous/common people of the State and became strong contender in the Assembly as well as Parliamentary elections. This party governed the State for brief period from 18 September to 31 October, 1979 with late Tomo Riba as the Chief Minister.
In the year 1989, most of the PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) leaders merged with Janata Dal leaving PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal) to be a registered regional party in the State.
However, in order to fulfill the dream of founding members of PPA (People’s Party of Arunachal), on August 22nd 2007, this party has been reorganized at Rajiv Gandhi University, Rono Hills. Shri Kamen Ringu, Shri Tamar Karlo and Dr. Ashan Riddi played leading role in reorganizing the party.
